text: Now when David had come to Mahanaim, Shobi the son of Nahash from Rabbah of the sons of Ammon, Machir the son of Ammiel from Lo-debar, and Barzillai the Gileadite from Rogelim,
speaker: Narrator

text: brought beds, basins, pottery, wheat, barley, flour, parched grain, beans, lentils, parched seeds,
speaker: Narrator

text: honey, curds, sheep, and cheese of the herd, for David and for the people who were with him, to eat; for they said, “The people are hungry and weary and thirsty in the wilderness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David numbered the people who were with him and set over them commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds.
speaker: Narrator

text: David sent the people out, one third under the command of Joab, one third under the command of Abishai the son of Zeruiah, Joab’s brother, and one third under the command of Ittai the Gittite. And the king said to the people, “I myself will surely go out with you also.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the people said, “You should not go out; for if we indeed flee, they will not care about us; even if half of us die, they will not care about us. But you are worth ten thousand of us; therefore now it is better that you be ready to help us from the city.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to them, “Whatever seems best to you I will do.” So the king stood beside the gate, and all the people went out by hundreds and thousands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king charged Joab and Abishai and Ittai, saying, “Deal gently for my sake with the young man Absalom.” And all the people heard when the king charged all the commanders concerning Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people went out into the field against Israel, and the battle took place in the forest of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Israel were defeated there before the servants of David, and the slaughter there that day was great, 20,000 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the battle there was spread over the whole countryside, and the forest devoured more people that day than the sword devoured.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Absalom happened to meet the servants of David. For Absalom was riding on his mule, and the mule went under the thick branches of a great oak. And his head caught fast in the oak, so he was left hanging between heaven and earth, while the mule that was under him kept going.
speaker: Narrator

text: When a certain man saw it, he told Joab and said, “Behold, I saw Absalom hanging in an oak.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab said to the man who had told him, “Now behold, you saw him! Why then did you not strike him there to the ground? And I would have given you ten pieces of silver and a belt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The man said to Joab, “Even if I should receive a thousand pieces of silver in my hand, I would not put out my hand against the king’s son; for in our hearing the king charged you and Abishai and Ittai, saying, ‘Protect for me the young man Absalom!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, if I had dealt treacherously against his life (and there is nothing hidden from the king), then you yourself would have stood aloof.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab said, “I will not waste time here with you.” So he took three spears in his hand and thrust them through the heart of Absalom while he was yet alive in the midst of the oak.
speaker: Narrator

text: And ten young men who carried Joab’s armor gathered around and struck Absalom and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab blew the trumpet, and the people returned from pursuing Israel, for Joab restrained the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took Absalom and cast him into a deep pit in the forest and erected over him a very great heap of stones. And all Israel fled, each to his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and set up for himself a pillar which is in the King’s Valley, for he said, “I have no son to preserve my name.” So he named the pillar after his own name, and it is called Absalom’s Monument to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ahimaaz the son of Zadok said, “Please let me run and bring the king news that the Lord has freed him from the hand of his enemies.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab said to him, “You are not the man to carry news this day, but you shall carry news another day; however, you shall carry no news today because the king’s son is dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab said to the Cushite, “Go, tell the king what you have seen.” So the Cushite bowed to Joab and ran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Ahimaaz the son of Zadok said once more to Joab, “But whatever happens, please let me also run after the Cushite.” And Joab said, “Why would you run, my son, since you will have no reward for going?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “But whatever happens,” he said, “I will run.” So he said to him, “Run.” Then Ahimaaz ran by way of the plain and passed up the Cushite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David was sitting between the two gates; and the watchman went up to the roof of the gate by the wall, and raised his eyes and looked, and behold, a man running by himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchman called and told the king. And the king said, “If he is by himself there is good news in his mouth.” And he came nearer and nearer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the watchman saw another man running; and the watchman called to the gatekeeper and said, “Behold, another man running by himself.” And the king said, “This one also is bringing good news.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchman said, “I think the running of the first one is like the running of Ahimaaz the son of Zadok.” And the king said, “This is a good man and comes with good news.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimaaz called and said to the king, “All is well.” And he prostrated himself before the king with his face to the ground. And he said, “Blessed is the Lord your God, who has delivered up the men who lifted their hands against my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “Is it well with the young man Absalom?” And Ahimaaz answered, “When Joab sent the king’s servant, and your servant, I saw a great tumult, but I did not know what it was.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said, “Turn aside and stand here.” So he turned aside and stood still.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the Cushite arrived, and the Cushite said, “Let my lord the king receive good news, for the Lord has freed you this day from the hand of all those who rose up against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to the Cushite, “Is it well with the young man Absalom?” And the Cushite answered, “Let the enemies of my lord the king, and all who rise up against you for evil, be as that young man!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king was deeply moved and went up to the chamber over the gate and wept. And thus he said as he walked, “O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! Would I had died instead of you, O Absalom, my son, my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then it was told Joab, “Behold, the king is weeping and mourns for Absalom.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The victory that day was turned to mourning for all the people, for the people heard it said that day, “The king is grieved for his son.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people went by stealth into the city that day, as people who are humiliated steal away when they flee in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king covered his face and cried out with a loud voice, “O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Joab came into the house to the king and said, “Today you have covered with shame the faces of all your servants, who today have saved your life and the lives of your sons and daughters, the lives of your wives, and the lives of your concubines,
speaker: Narrator

text: by loving those who hate you, and by hating those who love you. For you have shown today that princes and servants are nothing to you; for I know this day that if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead today, then you would be pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore arise, go out and speak kindly to your servants, for I swear by the Lord, if you do not go out, surely not a man will pass the night with you, and this will be worse for you than all the evil that has come upon you from your youth until now.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king arose and sat in the gate. When they told all the people, saying, “Behold, the king is sitting in the gate,” then all the people came before the king.
Now Israel had fled, each to his tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people were quarreling throughout all the tribes of Israel, saying, “The king delivered us from the hand of our enemies and saved us from the hand of the Philistines, but now he has fled out of the land from Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, Absalom, whom we anointed over us, has died in battle. Now then, why are you silent about bringing the king back?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David sent to Zadok and Abiathar the priests, saying, “Speak to the elders of Judah, saying, ‘Why are you the last to bring the king back to his house, since the word of all Israel has come to the king, even to his house?
speaker: Narrator

text: You are my brothers; you are my bone and my flesh. Why then should you be the last to bring back the king?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to Amasa, ‘Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God do so to me, and more also, if you will not be commander of the army before me continually in place of Joab.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus he turned the hearts of all the men of Judah as one man, so that they sent word to the king, saying, “Return, you and all your servants.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king then returned and came as far as the Jordan. And Judah came to Gilgal in order to go to meet the king, to bring the king across the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Shimei the son of Gera, the Benjamite who was from Bahurim, hurried and came down with the men of Judah to meet King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were a thousand men of Benjamin with him, with Ziba the servant of the house of Saul, and his fifteen sons and his twenty servants with him; and they rushed to the Jordan before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they kept crossing the ford to bring over the king’s household, and to do what was good in his sight. And Shimei the son of Gera fell down before the king as he was about to cross the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he said to the king, “Let not my lord consider me guilty, nor remember what your servant did wrong on the day when my lord the king came out from Jerusalem, so that the king would take it to heart.
speaker: Narrator

text: For your servant knows that I have sinned; therefore behold, I have come today, the first of all the house of Joseph to go down to meet my lord the king.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abishai the son of Zeruiah said, “Should not Shimei be put to death for this, because he cursed the Lord’s anointed?”
speaker: Narrator

text: David then said, “What have I to do with you, O sons of Zeruiah, that you should this day be an adversary to me? Should any man be put to death in Israel today? For do I not know that I am king over Israel today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Shimei, “You shall not die.” Thus the king swore to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Mephibosheth the son of Saul came down to meet the king; and he had neither cared for his feet, nor trimmed his mustache, nor washed his clothes, from the day the king departed until the day he came home in peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was when he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, that the king said to him, “Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he answered, “O my lord, the king, my servant deceived me; for your servant said, ‘I will saddle a donkey for myself that I may ride on it and go with the king,’ because your servant is lame.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, he has slandered your servant to my lord the king; but my lord the king is like the angel of God, therefore do what is good in your sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: For all my father’s household was nothing but dead men before my lord the king; yet you set your servant among those who ate at your own table. What right do I have yet that I should complain anymore to the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king said to him, “Why do you still speak of your affairs? I have decided, ‘You and Ziba shall divide the land.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Mephibosheth said to the king, “Let him even take it all, since my lord the king has come safely to his own house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Barzillai the Gileadite had come down from Rogelim; and he went on to the Jordan with the king to escort him over the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Barzillai was very old, being eighty years old; and he had sustained the king while he stayed at Mahanaim, for he was a very great man.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Barzillai, “You cross over with me and I will sustain you in Jerusalem with me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Barzillai said to the king, “How long have I yet to live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?
speaker: Narrator

text: I am now eighty years old. Can I distinguish between good and bad? Or can your servant taste what I eat or what I drink? Or can I hear anymore the voice of singing men and women? Why then should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant would merely cross over the Jordan with the king. Why should the king compensate me with this reward?
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let your servant return, that I may die in my own city near the grave of my father and my mother. However, here is your servant Chimham, let him cross over with my lord the king, and do for him what is good in your sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king answered, “Chimham shall cross over with me, and I will do for him what is good in your sight; and whatever you require of me, I will do for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people crossed over the Jordan and the king crossed too. The king then kissed Barzillai and blessed him, and he returned to his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king went on to Gilgal, and Chimham went on with him; and all the people of Judah and also half the people of Israel accompanied the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: And behold, all the men of Israel came to the king and said to the king, “Why had our brothers the men of Judah stolen you away, and brought the king and his household and all David’s men with him over the Jordan?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the men of Judah answered the men of Israel, “Because the king is a close relative to us. Why then are you angry about this matter? Have we eaten at all at the king’s expense, or has anything been taken for us?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the men of Israel answered the men of Judah and said, “We have ten parts in the king, therefore we also have more claim on David than you. Why then did you treat us with contempt? Was it not our advice first to bring back our king?” Yet the words of the men of Judah were harsher than the words of the men of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now a worthless fellow happened to be there whose name was Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjamite; and he blew the trumpet and said,
“We have no portion in David,
Nor do we have inheritance in the son of Jesse;
Every man to his tents, O Israel!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the men of Israel withdrew from following David and followed Sheba the son of Bichri; but the men of Judah remained steadfast to their king, from the Jordan even to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David came to his house at Jerusalem, and the king took the ten women, the concubines whom he had left to keep the house, and placed them under guard and provided them with sustenance, but did not go in to them. So they were shut up until the day of their death, living as widows.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king said to Amasa, “Call out the men of Judah for me within three days, and be present here yourself.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Amasa went to call out the men of Judah, but he delayed longer than the set time which he had appointed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David said to Abishai, “Now Sheba the son of Bichri will do us more harm than Absalom; take your lord’s servants and pursue him, so that he does not find for himself fortified cities and escape from our sight.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab’s men went out after him, along with the Cherethites and the Pelethites and all the mighty men; and they went out from Jerusalem to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: When they were at the large stone which is in Gibeon, Amasa came to meet them. Now Joab was dressed in his military attire, and over it was a belt with a sword in its sheath fastened at his waist; and as he went forward, it fell out.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said to Amasa, “Is it well with you, my brother?” And Joab took Amasa by the beard with his right hand to kiss him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amasa was not on guard against the sword which was in Joab’s hand so he struck him in the belly with it and poured out his inward parts on the ground, and did not strike him again, and he died. Then Joab and Abishai his brother pursued Sheba the son of Bichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there stood by him one of Joab’s young men, and said, “Whoever favors Joab and whoever is for David, let him follow Joab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Amasa lay wallowing in his blood in the middle of the highway. And when the man saw that all the people stood still, he removed Amasa from the highway into the field and threw a garment over him when he saw that everyone who came by him stood still.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he was removed from the highway, all the men passed on after Joab to pursue Sheba the son of Bichri.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now he went through all the tribes of Israel to Abel, even Beth-maacah, and all the Berites; and they were gathered together and also went after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They came and besieged him in Abel Beth-maacah, and they cast up a siege ramp against the city, and it stood by the rampart; and all the people who were with Joab were wreaking destruction in order to topple the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a wise woman called from the city, “Hear, hear! Please tell Joab, ‘Come here that I may speak with you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he approached her, and the woman said, “Are you Joab?” And he answered, “I am.” Then she said to him, “Listen to the words of your maidservant.” And he answered, “I am listening.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then she spoke, saying, “Formerly they used to say, ‘They will surely ask advice at Abel,’ and thus they ended the dispute.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am of those who are peaceable and faithful in Israel. You are seeking to destroy a city, even a mother in Israel. Why would you swallow up the inheritance of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab replied, “Far be it, far be it from me that I should swallow up or destroy!
speaker: Narrator

text: Such is not the case. But a man from the hill country of Ephraim, Sheba the son of Bichri by name, has lifted up his hand against King David. Only hand him over, and I will depart from the city.” And the woman said to Joab, “Behold, his head will be thrown to you over the wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the woman wisely came to all the people. And they cut off the head of Sheba the son of Bichri and threw it to Joab. So he blew the trumpet, and they were dispersed from the city, each to his tent. Joab also returned to the king at Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joab was over the whole army of Israel, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the Cherethites and the Pelethites;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Adoram was over the forced labor, and Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud was the recorder;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Sheva was scribe, and Zadok and Abiathar were priests;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ira the Jairite was also a priest to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now there was a famine in the days of David for three years, year after year; and David sought the presence of the Lord. And the Lord said, “It is for Saul and his bloody house, because he put the Gibeonites to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king called the Gibeonites and spoke to them (now the Gibeonites were not of the sons of Israel but of the remnant of the Amorites, and the sons of Israel made a covenant with them, but Saul had sought to kill them in his zeal for the sons of Israel and Judah).
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus David said to the Gibeonites, “What should I do for you? And how can I make atonement that you may bless the inheritance of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Gibeonites said to him, “We have no concern of silver or gold with Saul or his house, nor is it for us to put any man to death in Israel.” And he said, “I will do for you whatever you say.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they said to the king, “The man who consumed us and who planned to exterminate us from remaining within any border of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text: let seven men from his sons be given to us, and we will hang them before the Lord in Gibeah of Saul, the chosen of the Lord.” And the king said, “I will give them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king spared Mephibosheth, the son of Jonathan the son of Saul, because of the oath of the Lord which was between them, between David and Saul’s son Jonathan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king took the two sons of Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, Armoni and Mephibosheth whom she had borne to Saul, and the five sons of Merab the daughter of Saul, whom she had borne to Adriel the son of Barzillai the Meholathite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he gave them into the hands of the Gibeonites, and they hanged them in the mountain before the Lord, so that the seven of them fell together; and they were put to death in the first days of harvest at the beginning of barley harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Rizpah the daughter of Aiah took sackcloth and spread it for herself on the rock, from the beginning of harvest until it rained on them from the sky; and she allowed neither the birds of the sky to rest on them by day nor the beasts of the field by night.
speaker: Narrator

text: When it was told David what Rizpah the daughter of Aiah, the concubine of Saul, had done,
speaker: Narrator

text: then David went and took the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from the men of Jabesh-gilead, who had stolen them from the open square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hanged them on the day the Philistines struck down Saul in Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: He brought up the bones of Saul and the bones of Jonathan his son from there, and they gathered the bones of those who had been hanged.
speaker: Narrator

text: They buried the bones of Saul and Jonathan his son in the country of Benjamin in Zela, in the grave of Kish his father; thus they did all that the king commanded, and after that God was moved by prayer for the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now when the Philistines were at war again with Israel, David went down and his servants with him; and as they fought against the Philistines, David became weary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Ishbi-benob, who was among the descendants of the giant, the weight of whose spear was three hundred shekels of bronze in weight, was girded with a new sword, and he intended to kill David.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Abishai the son of Zeruiah helped him, and struck the Philistine and killed him. Then the men of David swore to him, saying, “You shall not go out again with us to battle, so that you do not extinguish the lamp of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now it came about after this that there was war again with the Philistines at Gob; then Sibbecai the Hushathite struck down Saph, who was among the descendants of the giant.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was war with the Philistines again at Gob, and Elhanan the son of Jaare-oregim the Bethlehemite killed Goliath the Gittite, the shaft of whose spear was like a weaver’s beam.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was war at Gath again, where there was a man of great stature who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in number; and he also had been born to the giant.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he defied Israel, Jonathan the son of Shimei, David’s brother, struck him down.
speaker: Narrator

text: These four were born to the giant in Gath, and they fell by the hand of David and by the hand of his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David spoke the words of this song to the Lord in the day that the Lord delivered him from the hand of all his enemies and from the hand of Saul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said,
“The Lord is my rock and my fortress and my deliverer;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“I call upon the Lord, who is worthy to be praised,
And I am saved from my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For the waves of death encompassed me;
The torrents of destruction overwhelmed me;
speaker: Narrator

text:
The cords of Sheol surrounded me;
The snares of death confronted me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“In my distress I called upon the Lord,
Yes, I cried to my God;
And from His temple He heard my voice,
And my cry for help came into His ears.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then the earth shook and quaked,
The foundations of heaven were trembling
And were shaken, because He was angry.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“He bowed the heavens also, and came down
With thick darkness under His feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And He rode on a cherub and flew;
And He appeared on the wings of the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And He made darkness canopies around Him,
A mass of waters, thick clouds of the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“From the brightness before Him
Coals of fire were kindled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord thundered from heaven,
And the Most High uttered His voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And He sent out arrows, and scattered them,
Lightning, and routed them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then the channels of the sea appeared,
The foundations of the world were laid bare
By the rebuke of the Lord,
At the blast of the breath of His nostrils.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He sent from on high, He took me;
He drew me out of many waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He delivered me from my strong enemy,
From those who hated me, for they were too strong for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They confronted me in the day of my calamity,
But the Lord was my support.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He also brought me forth into a broad place;
He rescued me, because He delighted in me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord has rewarded me according to my righteousness;
According to the cleanness of my hands He has recompensed me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For I have kept the ways of the Lord,
And have not acted wickedly against my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For all His ordinances were before me,
And as for His statutes, I did not depart from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I was also blameless toward Him,
And I kept myself from my iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Therefore the Lord has recompensed me according to my righteousness,
According to my cleanness before His eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“With the kind You show Yourself kind,
With the blameless You show Yourself blameless;
speaker: Narrator

text:
With the pure You show Yourself pure,
And with the perverted You show Yourself astute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And You save an afflicted people;
But Your eyes are on the haughty whom You abase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For You are my lamp, O Lord;
And the Lord illumines my darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For by You I can run upon a troop;
By my God I can leap over a wall.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“For who is God, besides the Lord?
And who is a rock, besides our God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“God is my strong fortress;
And He sets the blameless in His way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He makes my feet like hinds’ feet,
And sets me on my high places.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He trains my hands for battle,
So that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have also given me the shield of Your salvation,
And Your help makes me great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You enlarge my steps under me,
And my feet have not slipped.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I pursued my enemies and destroyed them,
And I did not turn back until they were consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And I have devoured them and shattered them, so that they did not rise;
And they fell under my feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“For You have girded me with strength for battle;
You have subdued under me those who rose up against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You have also made my enemies turn their backs to me,
And I destroyed those who hated me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They looked, but there was none to save;
Even to the Lord, but He did not answer them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Then I pulverized them as the dust of the earth;
I crushed and stamped them as the mire of the streets.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Foreigners pretend obedience to me;
As soon as they hear, they obey me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Foreigners lose heart,
And come trembling out of their fortresses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord lives, and blessed be my rock;
And exalted be God, the rock of my salvation,
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God who executes vengeance for me,
And brings down peoples under me,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
“Therefore I will give thanks to You, O Lord, among the nations,
And I will sing praises to Your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“He is a tower of deliverance to His king,
And shows lovingkindness to His anointed,
To David and his descendants forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now these are the last words of David.
David the son of Jesse declares,
The man who was raised on high declares,
The anointed of the God of Jacob,
And the sweet psalmist of Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Spirit of the Lord spoke by me,
And His word was on my tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The God of Israel said,
The Rock of Israel spoke to me,
‘He who rules over men righteously,
Who rules in the fear of God,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is as the light of the morning when the sun rises,
A morning without clouds,
When the tender grass springs out of the earth,
Through sunshine after rain.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Truly is not my house so with God?
For He has made an everlasting covenant with me,
Ordered in all things, and secured;
For all my salvation and all my desire,
Will He not indeed make it grow?
speaker: Narrator

text:
“But the worthless, every one of them will be thrust away like thorns,
Because they cannot be taken in hand;
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the man who touches them
Must be armed with iron and the shaft of a spear,
And they will be completely burned with fire in their place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of the mighty men whom David had: Josheb-basshebeth a Tahchemonite, chief of the captains, he was called Adino the Eznite, because of eight hundred slain by him at one time;
speaker: Narrator

text: and after him was Eleazar the son of Dodo the Ahohite, one of the three mighty men with David when they defied the Philistines who were gathered there to battle and the men of Israel had withdrawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: He arose and struck the Philistines until his hand was weary and clung to the sword, and the Lord brought about a great victory that day; and the people returned after him only to strip the slain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now after him was Shammah the son of Agee a Hararite. And the Philistines were gathered into a troop where there was a plot of ground full of lentils, and the people fled from the Philistines.
speaker: Narrator

text: But he took his stand in the midst of the plot, defended it and struck the Philistines; and the Lord brought about a great victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then three of the thirty chief men went down and came to David in the harvest time to the cave of Adullam, while the troop of the Philistines was camping in the valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was then in the stronghold, while the garrison of the Philistines was then in Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David had a craving and said, “Oh that someone would give me water to drink from the well of Bethlehem which is by the gate!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the three mighty men broke through the camp of the Philistines, and drew water from the well of Bethlehem which was by the gate, and took it and brought it to David. Nevertheless he would not drink it, but poured it out to the Lord;
speaker: Narrator

text: and he said, “Be it far from me, O Lord, that I should do this. Shall I drink the blood of the men who went in jeopardy of their lives?” Therefore he would not drink it. These things the three mighty men did.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai, the brother of Joab, the son of Zeruiah, was chief of the thirty. And he swung his spear against three hundred and killed them, and had a name as well as the three.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was most honored of the thirty, therefore he became their commander; however, he did not attain to the three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, the son of a valiant man of Kabzeel, who had done mighty deeds, killed the two sons of Ariel of Moab. He also went down and killed a lion in the middle of a pit on a snowy day.
speaker: Narrator

text: He killed an Egyptian, an impressive man. Now the Egyptian had a spear in his hand, but he went down to him with a club and snatched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with his own spear.
speaker: Narrator

text: These things Benaiah the son of Jehoiada did, and had a name as well as the three mighty men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was honored among the thirty, but he did not attain to the three. And David appointed him over his guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asahel the brother of Joab was among the thirty; Elhanan the son of Dodo of Bethlehem,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shammah the Harodite, Elika the Harodite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Helez the Paltite, Ira the son of Ikkesh the Tekoite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiezer the Anathothite, Mebunnai the Hushathite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zalmon the Ahohite, Maharai the Netophathite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Heleb the son of Baanah the Netophathite, Ittai the son of Ribai of Gibeah of the sons of Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah a Pirathonite, Hiddai of the brooks of Gaash,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abi-albon the Arbathite, Azmaveth the Barhumite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliahba the Shaalbonite, the sons of Jashen, Jonathan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shammah the Hararite, Ahiam the son of Sharar the Ararite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliphelet the son of Ahasbai, the son of the Maacathite, Eliam the son of Ahithophel the Gilonite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezro the Carmelite, Paarai the Arbite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Igal the son of Nathan of Zobah, Bani the Gadite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, armor bearers of Joab the son of Zeruiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
speaker: Narrator

text: Uriah the Hittite; thirty-seven in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now again the anger of the Lord burned against Israel, and it incited David against them to say, “Go, number Israel and Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said to Joab the commander of the army who was with him, “Go about now through all the tribes of Israel, from Dan to Beersheba, and register the people, that I may know the number of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab said to the king, “Now may the Lord your God add to the people a hundred times as many as they are, while the eyes of my lord the king still see; but why does my lord the king delight in this thing?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the king’s word prevailed against Joab and against the commanders of the army. So Joab and the commanders of the army went out from the presence of the king to register the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: They crossed the Jordan and camped in Aroer, on the right side of the city that is in the middle of the valley of Gad and toward Jazer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they came to Gilead and to the land of Tahtim-hodshi, and they came to Dan-jaan and around to Sidon,
speaker: Narrator

text: and came to the fortress of Tyre and to all the cities of the Hivites and of the Canaanites, and they went out to the south of Judah, to Beersheba.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when they had gone about through the whole land, they came to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Joab gave the number of the registration of the people to the king; and there were in Israel eight hundred thousand valiant men who drew the sword, and the men of Judah were five hundred thousand men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now David’s heart troubled him after he had numbered the people. So David said to the Lord, “I have sinned greatly in what I have done. But now, O Lord, please take away the iniquity of Your servant, for I have acted very foolishly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David arose in the morning, the word of the Lord came to the prophet Gad, David’s seer, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and speak to David, ‘Thus the Lord says, “I am offering you three things; choose for yourself one of them, which I will do to you.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gad came to David and told him, and said to him, “Shall seven years of famine come to you in your land? Or will you flee three months before your foes while they pursue you? Or shall there be three days’ pestilence in your land? Now consider and see what answer I shall return to Him who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to Gad, “I am in great distress. Let us now fall into the hand of the Lord for His mercies are great, but do not let me fall into the hand of man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent a pestilence upon Israel from the morning until the appointed time, and seventy thousand men of the people from Dan to Beersheba died.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the angel stretched out his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the Lord relented from the calamity and said to the angel who destroyed the people, “It is enough! Now relax your hand!” And the angel of the Lord was by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David spoke to the Lord when he saw the angel who was striking down the people, and said, “Behold, it is I who have sinned, and it is I who have done wrong; but these sheep, what have they done? Please let Your hand be against me and against my father’s house.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gad came to David that day and said to him, “Go up, erect an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David went up according to the word of Gad, just as the Lord had commanded.
speaker: Narrator

text: Araunah looked down and saw the king and his servants crossing over toward him; and Araunah went out and bowed his face to the ground before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Araunah said, “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” And David said, “To buy the threshing floor from you, in order to build an altar to the Lord, that the plague may be held back from the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Araunah said to David, “Let my lord the king take and offer up what is good in his sight. Look, the oxen for the burnt offering, the threshing sledges and the yokes of the oxen for the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Everything, O king, Araunah gives to the king.” And Araunah said to the king, “May the Lord your God accept you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: However, the king said to Araunah, “No, but I will surely buy it from you for a price, for I will not offer burnt offerings to the Lord my God which cost me nothing.” So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text: David built there an altar to the Lord and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. Thus the Lord was moved by prayer for the land, and the plague was held back from Israel.
speaker: Narrator
